Link Mash (May 22, 2014)

May 22, 2014
1 minute read

The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • babun/babun. A “linux-like console on a Windows host without a lot of fuzz…” Great to see Windows shells getting some love.
  • The Silver Searcher: Better than Ack. Searching text files quickly is a big deal. This is the most impressive tool I’ve seen in a long time.
  • Each Week, Two Anonymous Students Named Dangerdust Create This Amazing Chalkboard Art. Simply amazing.
  • Crazy Dude Builds Fully Automatic Wolverine Claws In His Garage. Because, why not???
  • import.io | Free Structured Web Data Scraping Tool. A very cool app; you need to see it to believe it.
  • Using Trello Like a Boss. A great collection of Trello tips, tricks, and ideas.
  • Seven Unsung Built-In Gems of Mac OS X. I usually don’t buy into these type of “did you know?” tech articles, but this list of OS X “gems” is actually quite surprising.
  • rupa/z. Tracks your most used directories, based on ‘frequency’ and allows you to get back to them easily.
  • Painless Vim. A great, easy-to-understand guide to vim for beginners.
  • Geeknote – Evernote console client for Linux, FreeBSD, OS X. Evernote on the command line?? Yes please.
  • The Most Common Two Minute Emails You Can Deal With Right Away. “According to GTD methodology, if something takes you less than two minutes, you should do it immediately — any more, and it goes on your to-do list.” This is a great reminder.
  • How digital detectives deciphered Stuxnet, the most menacing malware in history. Recently re-read this article; beyond being fascinating, it is especially potent given the recent activity of the NSA.

This Link Mash was generated by PinPress, a simple tool to generate text templates from Pinboard data.
